Lilibeth has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase sewing materials, equipment and supplies.

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en: Visitacion is married with seven children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Visitacion is 52 years old and has one child who is in school. Visitacion has a general store business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell. Visitacion has been in this business for four years. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is 54 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business selling footwear in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

Feliciana has borrowed and paid three previous loans from NWTF. She has been running the business selling footwear for five years and also earns an income from a general store and food vending. Feliciana aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional footwear to sell

loans.name: Ma. Jean

texts.en:
This is Ma. Jean, 43, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Joselito, a salesman, and she is a mother to her children. She manages their household while also operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Ma. Jean maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other companies. A customer's order is bought with cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. The dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. 

Ma. Jean also has a food stall. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week. To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 30,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ma. Jean hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to have a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and it is also where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Anilyn

texts.en:
Anilyn is 45 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Anilyn is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Anilyn has been farming rice for one year and also earns additional income from buying and selling dried coconut meat.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Joey

texts.en:
This is Joey, 28, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Paz, a vendor and mother of his child. Together they manage their household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Joey operates a junk shop. Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines, and while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic, paper and other materials. They sell these to junk shops for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean, and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories and others of the like. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. He will be incorporating the loan into his current revolving fund used to buy trash from collectors. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

Joey hopes to be able to expand soon, just as he fervently hopes that his child will be able to have good future through all his hard work on his business. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for recyclable materials needed in his business.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling dried fish business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks to sell through her dried fish business.

Arlene has been in this business for six years. Arlene earns additional income from farming rice.

Arlene has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure family's future.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks to sell.

loans.name: Auria

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Auria works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling vegetables. Auria is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store business.

Auria has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Joemar

texts.en:
This is Joemar; he previously accessed a 11,000 PHP loan that he utilized to buy more fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business. His earnings were a big help in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another 11,000 PHP loan. He will use the loan to buy more fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business. More items to sell will result for better profit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Joemar hopes to be able to expand his business soon and dreams of having his own family someday. He faithfully meets up with his fellowship* co-members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of fish ball products needed for his business.

loans.name: Amartuvshin

texts.en: Mrs. Amartuvshin is 38 years old and lives with her three children and her husband in a little house in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her older daughter just became a university student, and her other children are in high school. She has worked in the food market as a salesperson. She recently started her own business selling fruits and vegetables and other food in another food market. She is planning to increase her turnover and to have her own workplace. She is an open-minded and diligent woman. who says "This year, my daughter become a college student. Thus, I need to pay her college tuition fee and other expenses". She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to pay her daughter's tuition and other school-related expenses.

loans.use: to pay her daughter's tuition and other school-related expenses.

loans.name: Akouavi Clarisse

texts.fr: Agée de 35ans, Akouavi Clarisse est mariée et mère de trois enfants âgés respectivement de 08 à 03ans. Coiffeuse de formation, elle a un atelier où elle vend des mèches, des miroirs et des appareils séchoirs depuis quelques années. Elle s'approvisionne dans l'un des marchés du Bénin et sa clientèle est essentiellement composée des béninoises et des togolaises. Dans le but d'accroître son pouvoir d'achat et de couvrir la demande de ses clients, Akouavi Clarisse a sollicité et a obtenu un financement auprès de Finadev afin de maximiser son bénéfice et de participer à la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en: 35-year-old Akouavi Clarisse is married and the mother of 3 children, aged between 3 and 8 years. A hairdresser by profession, she has a hair salon where she has been selling hair extensions, mirrors and hair dryers for several years. She gets her supplies at one of Benin's markets and her clientèle is mainly made up of women from Benin and Togo. With a view to increasing her buying power and meeting her customer demand, Akouavi Clarisse has requested and received funding from Finadev so that she can maximise her profits and help her children get an education.

loans.use: to buy 10 lots of hair extensions, 1 hair dryer and one mirror.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy vegetables for sale in her home-based business.

loans.name: Berlyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Berlyn works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from buying & selling charcoal. Berlyn is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase additional vegetables to sell in her business.

Berlyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Faalata

texts.en: Faalata is 25 years old, single with no children. She runs a small business selling cabbages and tomatoes in her community.  She has been in business for two years. Faalata has requested a loan to buy a rake, gloves, a wheelbarrow and water hose for her business. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to capital. With her earnings, Faalata will save her profit to help with her family expenses.

loans.use: to buy a rake, gloves, a wheelbarrow and water hose for her business.

loans.name: Peniamina

texts.en:
Peniamina is 23 years old and single with no children. For three years, she has run a small business selling cabbages, cucumbers and tomatoes in her community. 

Peniamina has requested a loan to buy a wheelbarrow, rake, gloves, boots, vegetable seeds and barbed wire for her business. She joined SPBD in 2010 to gain access to capital. Peniamina will save her profits to help her family with expenses and to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a wheelbarrow, rake, gloves, boots, vegetable seeds and barbed wire.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy animals for her animal-selling business.

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en:
Akenese is an 18-year-old, married woman with no children. 

She has a small plantation and grows taro and bananas to earn a living. She has been doing this for one year. Akenese has requested a loan to buy baby crops, barbed wire, a knife and boots.

Akenese became a member of SPBD in 2012. With her profits, Akenese hopes to extend her business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy baby crops, barbed wire, a knife and boots.

loans.name: Emelinda

texts.en:
Emelinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to purchase additional fruits and vegetables to sell in her business.

Emelinda has been in this business for nine years. She earns additional income from raising vegetables on a farm.

Emelinda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to she can be able to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of fuirts and vegetables to sell in her business.

loans.name: Eve

texts.en:
Kalameli is 42 years old and married with five children. She runs a small business selling pancakes in her community. She has been doing this for two years. 

Kalameli has requested a loan to buy flour, sugar, oil and plastic bags for her business. She joined SPBD in 2010 to gain access to capital. Kalameli will save her profits to support the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, oil and plastic bags for her business.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita is 49 years old and married with six children. With two children in school, Estelita works very hard to provide for them.

Estelita runs a general store in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell.

Estelita has been in this business for nine years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, soft drinks, sugar, soap, noodles, etc.

In the future, Estelita would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
This is Marilou, 43, a resident of Malibay, Philippines. Her husband is Felino, a vendor, and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Marilou operates a buying and selling business. What she basically does is buy undergarments from wholesalers and sells them per piece/pack with a profit. The products can include underwear, handkerchiefs  and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are students and mall patrons. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products and supplies to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Marilou dreams to have her own house and lot and hopes to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of supplies and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Eugenia works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling of charcoal business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store. Eugenia is borrowing 13,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell for her charcoal business.

Eugenia has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes for a clothes selling business.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
This is Alicia. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a new 25,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Alicia dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en:
Elisapeta is a 37-year-old married woman with six children. She has a small plantation and grows taro, bananas and yams to earn a living. She has been doing this for five years. Elisapeta has requested a loan to to buy bush knives, a rake, boots, a water hose and barbed wire.

She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. With her profits, Elisapeta hopes to save more for her kids' education.

loans.use: to buy bush knives, a rake, boots, a water hose and barbed wire.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Evangeline works hard to support her family.

Her business is selling herbal medicine in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from buying and selling water buffalo. 

Evangeline is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks to sell for her herbal medicine business.

Evangeline has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Amidou

texts.fr:
Monsieur AMIDOU est né vers 1968 à Ougan cercle de SIKASSO. Père de 7 enfants il vit dans une famille traditionnelle à Noumousso – Kadiolo.
 Il possède une boutique afin de bien mener son activité de commerce (céréales, sucre, huile, autres articles de boutique) depuis près de 10 ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et réçoit des commandes de céréales, notamment du riz. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ces clients, il collabore avec l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 6 ans.  Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 1tonne de sucre, 5 bidons de 20 litres d’huile et 3paquets biscuits. Il s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Kadiolo le jour de foire. Il les revend au comptant, sur commande, en gros et en détail dans sa boutique à Kadiolo à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 80 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer les intérêts de son prêt de résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses et investir le reste dans son activité.
Il compte acheter deux  tonnes de ciments pour achever la construction de son  terrain à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. AMIDOU was born around 1968 in Ougan, SIKASSO. A father of seven children, he lives in a traditional family in Noumousso, Kadiolo. He owns a shop where he has been selling various staples (cereals, sugar, oil, etc.) for nearly ten years. His experience has earned him a good reputation in his business. He receives orders for cereals such as rice. 

To have the resources needed to meet customer demand, he joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso six years ago. All past loans were repaid without incident. 

This loan will allow him to buy one ton of sugar, five 20-liter jugs of oil, and three packages of cookies. He buys his stock at the big market of Kadiolo on fair day. He conducts his sales at his shop for cash, on order, wholesale and at retail, to a clientele consisting of both men and women.

He hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 80,000 FCFA. This profit will allow him to pay the loan interest and to cover most of his expenses, any remainder to be reinvested in his activity. He plans to buy two tons of concrete to finish the land improvements needed to build housing.

loans.use: to buy various staples for his store.

loans.name: Salai

texts.en:
Salai is a 27-year-old married woman with four children.
 
She started a small plantation to grow taro, bananas and yams to earn a living. She has been doing this for one year. 

Salai has requested a loan to buy a rake, barbed wire, a water container, bush knives and boots. 

She has been a member of SPBD since 2012. With her profits, Salai hopes to save for her children's educations.

loans.use: to buy a rake, barbed wire, a water container, bush knives and boots.

loans.name: Tupe

texts.en:
Tupe is a 59-year-old married woman with five children.
 
She started a small plantation to grow taro, bananas and yams to earn a living. She has been doing this for one year.

Tupe has requested a loan to buy fertilizer, a wheelbarrow, boots, bush knives and barbed wire.
 
She has been a member of SPBD since 2012. With her profits, Salai hopes to save for her children's education and to extend the business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, a wheelbarrow, boots, bush knives and barbed wire.

loans.name: Mariyana

texts.en:
Based on her success with the first loan, Mariyana decided to get a new loan of 10M IDR, half of which will be used to buy glass shelving for her kiosk and half to buy an engine for her husband's boat. The boat’s engine he has now is old and often broken, so he needs to buy a new boat’s engine to support his business to deliver the guests. 

Mariyana and her husband will work together to repay the loan. With the business they pursue at this time, they have a dream to repair the house.

loans.use: To buy a glass shelf and a boat's engine.

loans.name: Jeaneth

texts.en:
Jeaneth is 28 years old and married with two children.

Jeaneth works hard to provide for her family. She runs a charcoal business in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy sacks of charcoal to sell.

Jeaneth has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the charcoal business for eight years and also earns an income from a general store.

Jeaneth aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes for selling on profit.

loans.name: Rasha’A

texts.en: Rasha’a is a 25-year-old mother of three. She lives with her kids in their small house. She has a small store that she owns and uses to sell a variety of products to the neighborhood and people around. She would like to get the youth loan so she can buy more products and sell to more people so she can increase her sales and support her three little kids.

loans.use: To bring more products to the store

loans.name: Mayasar

texts.en: Maysar is a 22 year old single lady living east of Amman. She works in her own home making cloaks and dresses so she can support herself and cover her expenses. She wishes to get a youth loan so she can buy more raw materials like fabric and threads to make new products and save more money so she can one day start her own shop.

loans.use: buy more raw materials like fabric and threads

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy food making ingredients for a food selling business.

loans.name: Noor

texts.en: Noor is 20 years old, married and lives with her husband and children in DirAlla. Her husband is a government employee. She decided to start a small business trading various products such as bed covers to sell to her neighborhood and friends. She has been doing so for two years now and hopes to get a youth loan so she can buy new products and cover more areas and increase her customers.

loans.use: buy new products and cover more areas to sell various products.

loans.name: Areen

texts.en:
Areen is a 24-year-old conservative woman, so she asked her husband to take her place in the photo.

Areen helps her husband run their small cellphone and accessories shop.  It is the only shop serving the area where they live in Madaba. And so she would like to get a youth loan so they can buy new products for their shop and increase their sales and profit.

loans.use: To buy new products for her cellphone shop.

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
This is Jesus, 66, a resident of Malibay, Philippines. He is married to Cristeta, a housewife, and is father to their children. He, together with his wife, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to provide for their everyday expenses.

Jesus operates a repair shop. He offers repair, check-up and reconditioning of electric fans, televisions, radios and other appliances.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. He will be using the loan to buy supplies like wiring, putty paint and others of the like. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

Jesus dreams to expand his business through all his hard work. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for materials like wiring, putty paint and others of the like.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima works hard to support her family. Fatima is married and has dry goods business in the Philippines. Fatima has been in this business for ten years now.

Fatima requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell.

In the future, Fatima would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Irien

texts.en:
Irien is 26 years old and married with two children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Irien runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy stock to sell in her general store. Irien has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as shampoo, toothpaste, canned goods, soft drinks, soap, etc. 

In the future, Irien would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Rania

texts.en:
Rania is a conservative woman, so she asked her husband, who works as a truck driver to take her place in the photo.

Rania is an active young woman living in Wihdat. She has her own business that she runs from home making embroidery and knitting and sewing clothes to sell. Being a smart and strategic thinker, she wants a youth loan to buy more fabric and thread so she can work on covering larger areas displaying her products and selling to new customers and not just relying on her neighbors and friends.

loans.use: to buy more fabric and thread

loans.name: Wisam

texts.en:
Wisam is 20 years old and from Gaza. Since 2010, he has owned a barbershop and is well-known in his area.

He asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy an air conditioner, barber chairs and some furniture for the shop. He hopes that this loan will help him increase the number of customers, and improve his income.

loans.use: to buy an air conditioner, barber chairs and some furniture for the shop.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a Palestinian single young man, he is a 21 years old and has had a store selling different types of home furniture for one year.

Ali wants to meet the demand of his clients in furniture, so he needs to take a loan from Faten to complete the price of purchasing different types of home furniture such as living-room furniture and bedroom furniture, that customers often request and buy, especially since Ali has a good reputation among customers and his store is located in a good commercial area in the market.

Ali is looking in the future to expand his store and bring in more types of home furniture.

Ali is photographed in his store and his loan is considered a Youth loan.

loans.use: To purchase more furniture for sale

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is 21 years old and from Gaza. She has owned a salon since January, 2012.

She asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy an air conditioner, makeup, and hair dryers for her salon, and to make some change in the decoration.

She hopes that this loan will help her increase her customers and improve her income.

loans.use: to buy an air conditioner, makeup, and hair dryers for her salon, and to make some change in the decoration.

loans.name: Yacoub

texts.en:
Yacoub is 23 years old and from Gaza. Since 2011, he has owned a shop selling clothes for women and children. 

He asked Ryada for this youth loan in order to buy display glass, install shelves, an aluminum door and improve some of the decoration of the shop.

He hopes that this loan will help him increase his income and thus lead to him owning a bigger shop in the area.

loans.use: to buy display glass, install shelves, an aluminum door and improve some of the decoration of the shop.

loans.name: Naema

texts.en:
For cultural reasons, Naema prefers that her photo not be on the Internet.  Thus the photo is of her husband Ahmad.   

Naema is a 21-year-old Palestinian young woman.  She is married to Ahmad and mother to one son and two daughters.

For the past two years, Naema's husband has had a bookstore.  It has been profitable and the only source of income to the family, but also it needs more support to cover the costs.  And because of the start of the new school year, Naema wants to help her husband in paying the cost of purchasing the new collection of school stationery that students request and purchase.  Naema is requesting a Youth loan from Faten for this purpose.

What distinguishes this project is that it is the only one in the area where they live. Taking this loan will increase sales and improve the family's income, which will enable them to live in better conditions.

Naema and her husband are looking to expand the bookstore in the future and have a variety of stationery for sale.

loans.use: To purchase a collection of school stationery for sale.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is 20 years from Gaza.  He is an ambitious guy who wants his own start-up project to open a grocery store.

He asked Ryada for this loan in order to buy display refrigerators, an electricity generator, shelves and a banner for the name of the store.
He hopes that this loan will help him open his project and provide him with a stable source of income to build himself a better future.

Ryada's Startup Loan is exclusively for borrowers who are beginning new enterprises, not for existing projects. To qualify, a borrower must show a clear business plan and realistic potential for success. The borrower must also invest his or her own money and resources into at least 50 percent of the startup enterprise. Ryada believes strongly in the potential of these borrowers and grants them a three-month grace period to help them get their business off the ground.

loans.use: to buy display refrigerators, an electricity generator, shelves and a banner for the name of the store.

loans.name: Gulshaniston

texts.en: Gulshaniston is 37 year old. She is married and has 2 children. She began her own animal husbandry business 2 years ago. Now she is one of the best and most successful business women in the local market. She buys cows, cares of them for 2 or 3 months, and then sells to local people. Thanks to her work, her cows are fat and attract a lot of customers. She wants to buy more cattle for developing the business but she does not have the money for it. She is asking for a loan to buy cattle. In this way she will provide her family with high quality of living conditions. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Uriel Enrique

texts.es: Uriel con su credikiva compró al por mayor y de contado, telas, para elaborar y vender ropa especialmente jeanes y camisetas deportivas. Con su crédito de Kiva quedó muy satisfecho, porque aumentó un poco su capital de trabajo y esto lo ha entusiasmado para continuar con su propósito de crecimiento. Ahora está aplicando a un nuevo financiamiento y con él comprará insumos como telas, hilos, accesorios,  para confeccionar ropa alusiva a las fiestas de fin de año y al a moda.   Él envía el siguiente  mensaje a los financiadores es el siguiente: “Estoy muy agradecido con Kiva y con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, espero seguir recibiendo este apoyo para seguir progresando empresarial y familiarmente. “
texts.en:
With his loan from Kiva, Uriel bought fabric wholesale with cash to make and sell clothing, especially jeans and sports shirts. He was very happy with his Kiva loan because it increased his working capital a little, and this gave him enthusiasm to continue with his intention to grow.

Now he is applying for new financing, and with it he will buy supplies such as fabrics, thread, and accessories in order to make clothing that hints at New Year's Eve parties and is in fashion. He sends the following message to those who support him financially: "I am very grateful to Kiva and to La Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, and I hope to continue receiving this support in order to continue making progress in business and domestically."

loans.use: to buy supplies such as fabrics, thread, and accessories to make clothing.

loans.name: Mujeres De Familia Group

texts.es:
Este Banco Comunal se llama “Mujeres de Familia” está conformado por 18 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros, entre los cuales se encuentran; cosmetología, costuras, venta de alfombras, ropa, bazar, comida rápida, artesanía, servicios entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la ciudad de Coronel.
Angelina, integrante del grupo del Banco Comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra sentada en primera fila, ocupando el primer lugar de derecha a izquierda, viste una chaqueta de color rosado, pantalón y botines de color negro, su cabello es de color castaño claro y lo usa suelto.
Ella se dedica al rubro de confección, desde hace 4 años. Comenta que además se dedica a otros rubros como artesanía, bordados, venta de ropa y accesorios para damas, trabaja algunas veces en su casa y otras veces va de puerta en puerta ofreciendo su mercadería, su horario de trabajo lo distribuye de acuerdo a su disponibilidad.
La mercadería e insumos que va necesitando los compra en la ciudad de Concepción en cordonerías, locales y distribuidoras donde encuentra articulos de artesanía y accesorios a bajo costo, por lo tanto conveniente económicamente.
Con el crédito comprará ropa para dama, accesorios como carteras, pulseras, para abastecer su negocio.
Una de las metas de Angelina es colocar una boutique donde pueda mostrar toda su mercadería ordenadamente a su clientela, y para generar mayores ingresos, así con esto optar a una mejor calidad de vida.
Angelina vive junto a su marido y sus cuatros hijos de 19, 16, 12 y 4 años de edad. Sus sueños a nivel familiar que crezca su negocio para darles un buen pasar a sus hijos y un buen futuro en  los estudios, para que sean grandes profesionales.
Ella se encuentra muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad brindada por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio. Respecto al grupo del Banco Comunal del cual forma parte, comenta que en éste existe muy buena comunicación. Por otro lado las capacitaciones, le han servido para aprender nuevas estrategias de venta y contabilidad.
Coronel es una comuna ubicada al sur de Chile, cerca de la ciudad de Concepción, región del Bíobío. Posee una economía basada en servicios, explotación forestal, agricultura. Cuenta también con una importante tradición minera en carbón, actividad que ya no se realiza, pero de la cual quedó la mina de carbón “Chiflón Puchoco”, convertida ahora en museo minero.
texts.en:
This communal bank is named "Family Women" (Mujeres de Familia), and it is made up of 18 entrepreneurs who are engaged in different economic activities, among which are: cosmetology, sewing, selling carpets, clothes, variety shops, fast food, crafts, services, and others. All the members are from the city of Coronel.

Angelina is a member of the communal bank.  She is sitting in the front row and is the first one on the right in the picture, wearing a pink jacket, pants and boots in black, her hair is light brown, and she wears it loose.  She has been in the business of sewing clothing for the past four years.  She says that she also engages in other work, such as handicrafts, embroidery, selling clothing and accessories for women, and that she works at home sometimes, and sometimes goes door to door offering her merchandise.  Her work schedule is varied according to her availability.

The goods and supplies that she needs, she buys in the city of Concepción in Cordonerías, where there are local distributors of handicrafts and accessories at low cost, which makes this economically smart.  With her loan, she will buy women's clothing, accessories like handbags, and bracelets, to restock her business.  One of Angela's goals is to find a boutique where she could show all her goods neatly arranged for her customers to look at, and to generate more income for a better quality of life.

Angelina lives with her husband and their four children, ages 19, 16, 12 and 4 years old.  Their dreams as a family are to grow their business to give a good future to her children and the education they need to become white-collar workers.  She is very happy and grateful for the opportunity provided by Fondo Esperanza, which allows her to invest in her business.  About the community bank where is a member, says that they have very good communication in their group. Furthermore, she says that their trainings have helped her learn new sales strategies and accounting.

Coronel is a community located in the south of Chile, near the city of Concepción, Biobío Region.  It has an economy based on services, forest harvesting, and agriculture. It also has a strong history in coal mining, an activity that is not currently performed, but which was exemplified by the coal mine "Chiflón Puchoco," which is now a mining museum.

loans.use: to buy women's clothing, accessories like purses and bracelets, and to stock her store.

loans.name: Jeannilyn

texts.en:
Jeannilyn is 49 years old and married with seven children.  She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. 

Jeannilyn is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to pay for rice seeds, hire laborers and buy additional farm equipment.  She has been farming rice for nine years and also earns additional income from selling dried coconut meat.

Jeannilyn is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to pay for rice seeds, hire laborers and buy additional farm equipment.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
This is Lorena. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a new 15,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Lorena hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn works hard to support her family. Jocelyn is 45 years old, married, and has a general store in the Philippines.

Jocelyn requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

Jocelyn has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Jocelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Joe Ann

texts.en:
Joe Ann is 24 years old and married with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Joe Ann owns a general store in the Philippines. Joe Ann requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her general store.

Joe Ann has been in this business for three years. In the future, Joe Ann would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
Firuza is 34 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and 3 children. She has had her own business for 3 years, and it is her source of income. She sells sugar, rice, beans, eggs, soft drinks, etc. 

She has had fewer customers lately, so she decided to widen the assortment of her goods. She is asking a loan of 3000 Somoni. With the loan she is going to buy dairy products, meats and cold cuts, as she wishes to satisfy the demand from her customers and always keep her store well-stocked. 
Her goal is to always keep her business brisk, as it is the source of income for her family.

loans.use: To buy food items to sell

loans.name: Sojida

texts.ru: Cочида - клиентка, которая успешно закончила свой кредит, и  вот решила получить очередной кредит на закуп сезонного ассортимента  детской одежды. После предыдущего кредита у неё увеличился товарооборот,а следовательно и доход. Она смогла запастись на зиму  углём для отопления дома. Сочида благодарна организации за финансовую поддержку и понимание потому что благодаря этой организации она намного улучшила свои условия проживания.  Планирует поехать за товаром в другой город и закупить зимнюю детскую одежду.
texts.en:
Sojida is a client who successfully repaid her loan, and who decided to take a concurrent loan for the purchase of seasonal assortment of children's clothing. After the previous loan her turnover increased, and consequently also her income. She managed to stock up coal for heating her home for the winter. 

Sojida is thankful to the organization for the financial support and understanding, because thanks to this organization she improved her living conditions a lot. She plans to travel to get merchandise at another city and purchase children's winter clothing.

loans.use: to purchase children's winter clothing

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy ingredients for her snack selling business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell, including shirts, dresses and pants.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina is 56 years old. She is from Poblacion, Baclayon, Bohol. For 20 years, she has been making home-baked snack foods to sell in her community. She makes polvoron (powdered milk candy that is made with flour, sugar, butter, and powdered milk), which she sells and delivers to nearby stores. She is asking for a loan to buy flour, sugar, and cellophane for her business. She hopes that she can expand her business to include other types of snack foods so that she can make a better income.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, and cellophane

loans.name: Shuhratjon

texts.ru: Шухратчон с 1977 года рождения, женат и имеет 4 детей.  Его жена в данное время не работает,  и занимается воспитанием  детей.  Шухратчон на протяжении 5 лет занимается производством пластиковых окон и дверей. Этим производством он занимается у себя в мастерской, которая находится  неподалеку от дома.  Шухратчон хочет получить  кредит в   "Арванд"  для расширения своей деятельности и улучшения благосостояния своей семьи. На полученный кредит Шухрат  хочет купить стекла и пластиковые рамки.  Он выражает огромную благодарность этой организации за финансовую поддержку!
texts.en: Shuhratjon was born in 1977. He is married and has four children. Shuhratjon currently does not work, as he is raising his children. Over the last five years, Shuhratjon has worked manufacturing plastic windows and doors. He does this manufacturing in his workshop, located not far from his home.  Shuhratjon would like to receive a loan from "Arvand" for the expansion of his activities and for the improvement of his family's well-being. With the received loan, Shuratjon wants to buy glass and plastic frames. He thanks this organization tremendously for the financial assistance!

loans.use: to purchase of glasses and plastic frames

loans.name: Soat

texts.en: Soat lives in a village with his wife and 4 children. The family gathers their main income from farming; they cultivate potatoes and onions and grow fruit trees. In addition to farming, Soat also would like to get involved in cattle breeding. He has applied for this loan to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizers. He awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona is 44 years old and married with three children. She works very hard to provide for them. Chona runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery items to sell. Chona has been in this business for 3 years and sells a variety of items such as soap, diapers, snack foods and other groceries. 

In the future, Chona would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya is 40 years old and married with seven children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Ligaya has been raising pigs for 10 years and also earns additional income from food vending. 

Ligaya is borrowing 22,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Rosarion

texts.en:
Rosarion works hard to support her family. She is married and has a welding shop in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 5 years.

Rosario requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy tools and equipment for her welding shop.

In the future, Rosario would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and equipment for her welding shop.

loans.name: Omar

texts.es:
Omar tiene 22 años y nació en Cali, Colombia. En estos momentos se encuentra estudiando psicología en la Universidad Pública del Valle gracias al esfuerzo de sus padres por darle una educación de calidad en una de las mejores universidades públicas del país.

Omar tiene el sueño de realizar una maestría en Psicología Clínica en el Reino Unido y el apoyo de Kiva es la única alternativa para pagar los gastos de inscripción, preparación de los exámenes de idioma y traducciones necesarias para la aplicación.

Aquí está su historia:

La vida académica e investigativa de mi disciplina de formación ha ocupado un lugar preponderante en mi vida y considero de vital importancia fortalecer este aspecto en la vía de aportar al desarrollo humano del contexto que me rodea. Ello requiere emprender un proceso de formación el cual anhelo empezar en cuanto reciba mi título profesional en psicología.

Tengo un gran sueño y plan de vida, y esto requiere empezar una maestría en el área de la psicología clínica en países en los cuales se haya desarrollado la disciplina ampliamente y me permitan traer elementos vitales para contribuir al fortalecimiento de la misma en el país. 

Sé  que no es un camino fácil, pero estoy dispuesto a emprenderlo con todos los recursos personales que poseo. Sin embargo, hay otro tipo de recursos los cuales en este momento de mi vida no tengo, ya que para cumplir mis metas es necesario empezar la maestría el próximo año y ello requiere empezar a prepararme para la certificación de un segundo idioma, establecer los procesos de evaluación, y posteriormente, la gestión de documentos para ser enviados a las Universidades a las cuales me voy a postular. 

Es fundamental en esta medida, contar con el apoyo de Kiva que sirva de puente entre mis sueños y metas, y yo.
texts.en:
Omar is 22 and was born in Cali, Colombia. At present he is studying psychology at the Universidad Pública del Valle (Valley State University) through the hard work of his parents, who are giving him a quality education in one of the best universities in the country.

Omar has a dream of pursuing a Master's degree in clinical psychology in the UK, and the support of Kiva is the only way to pay the registration fee, language test preparation, and the translations required for his application.

Here's his story:

"The life of academic and research training of my discipline has occupied an important place in my life, and I consider it of vital importance to further strengthen this aspect in my journey toward making a contribution to human development in the context that surrounds me. This requires undertaking a training process which I began to yearn for upon receiving my professional degree in psychology.

"I have a great dream and plan for my life, and this requires beginning a Master's in the field of clinical psychology in countries where the discipline has already developed broadly, and this will allow me to bring back vital elements to help strengthen the discipline in my own country.

"I know it's not an easy road, but I am willing to undertake it with all the personal resources I possess. Without a doubt, there are types of resources which at this point in my life I do not yet have, since in order to meet my goals, it will be necessary to begin my Master's degree in the next year, and this requires me to start preparing for my certification in a second language, establish the process for admission, and subsequently manage the creation or acquisition of documents to be sent to the universities to which I'm going to apply.

"Fundamental to this measure, I am counting on the support of Kiva as a bridge between my dreams and goals and myself."

loans.use: to pay the expense of applying for his Master's degree in Clinical Psychology.

loans.name: Al-Brah Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Brah, and consists of four ladies who live in Sana`a, Yemen.  This is a group of hardworking women, and they applied for a loan of 60000 YER.

Group member Jamila is a 25 year old married woman who has one child and is from Sana`a, Yemen. She is requesting a youth loan of 30000 YER to pay for her home improvements. She would like to buy new furniture and do maintenance on the home. 

In the future, she wants to expand her home to provide a good environment to live in.

loans.use: to buy new furniture and do maintenance on her home.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes for selling

loans.name: Merla

texts.en:
This is Merla, She previously accessed an 19,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 24,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Merla hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of giving her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Felimon

texts.en:
This is Felimon, 54, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Veronica and is a father to his children. He and his wife manage their household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide for his family.

Felimon operates a food stall, where he sells fish balls. In the Philippines, fish balls are commonly sold on the side of the street. They are served skewered, and can be dipped into different kinds of sauces. Fish balls are somewhat flat in shape, and are often made with the meat of cuttlefish. His other products include squid balls and quail eggs.  His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, Felimon is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fish ball ingredients and other ingredients needed in his business. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.

Felimon hopes to be able to expand soon. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more quantities of fish ball ingredients and other ingredients needed in his business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has one child who goes to school. She has no additional family members. She sells second-hand shoes at the market. She sells her products on retail basis. She has been in this business for the last five years. She works seven days a week.  She has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy a bale of second-hand shoes. Her major business challenges are ever-increasing prices of used shoes in Uganda and seasonality. Her goals are to become a wholesaler and to buy her own house. She lives in a rented house with no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy a bale of used shoes

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store in the Philippines. She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional inventory to sell in her general store. Lolita has been in this business for nine years. She earns additional income from selling charcoal and bananas. 

Lolita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business in order to secure the financial stability of her family. This is her second loan in Kiva.

loans.use: To buy inventory to sell in her general store

loans.name: Nevis

texts.es: Nevis vive al norte de la ciudad con su esposo y sus dos hijos en las edades de 11 y 15 años. Ella desde hace  20 años, está dedicada al comercio; negocio que nació cuando decidió darle curso libre a su espíritu independiente,  para lograr generar ingresos con los cuales responder a sus gastos personales. En su negocio vende productos cosméticos, calzado, colonia, ropa exterior e interior y la distribuye directamente a crédito, mientras la compra de contado. Su día laboral se inicia a las 8 de la mañana y finaliza a las 6 de la tarde todos los días, en los cuales ofrece sus productos a los clientes,  mediante guías especializadas o catálogos, atendiendo sus necesidades y logrando  hacer negociaciones que los beneficien, pues está atenta a los descuentos que estas revistas ofrecen, para trasladarle este beneficio a su clientela, a quien tanto cuida. Su meta mas adelante es abrir una miscelánea al público, para captar el mercado que la rodea, porque muchos de ellos desconoce que existe este negocio y un punto comercial resolvería esta situación. En un futuro sueña con que sus hijos se terminen de educar con calidad, para que tengan un gran potencial de ser exitosos y esto es su motivación más importante. En la actualidad está aplicando aun credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace ala Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará cremas, perfumes, productos capilares, ropa exterior, calzado y accesorios;  invirtiendo su credikiva en esta temporada de gran movimiento comercial, las ventas tienen una gran probabilidad de aumentar contundentemente, como le ocurre todos los finales de año y esto es lo que hace que su credikiva sea exitoso.
texts.en:
Nevis lives in the north of the city with her husband and two children, ages 11 and 15.  For the last 20 years she has worked in sales.  Her business was born when she decided to give free reign to her independent spirit in order to earn income to cover her personal expenses.  In her business, she sells cosmetics, shoes, cologne, undergarments and clothes.  She distributes them on credit, but she purchases them with immediate payment.  

During her work day, which starts at 8 in the morning and ends at 6 in the afternoon every day, she offers her customers products from specialized guide books or catalogs.  She attends to their needs and successfully makes negotiations which benefit them.  She is attentive to the discounts offered in the magazines in order to pass the benefits on to her customers, for whom she cares so much.  

Her goal for the future is to open a general store to the public in order to capture the market surrounding her because a lot of people don’t know that this type of business exists and a commercial location would resolve this situation.  She dreams that in the future her children will complete a quality education so that they have great potential to be successful and that is her most important motivation.  

Presently she is applying for a Kiva loan, her first financing from the Foundation Mario Santo Domingo, with which she will buy creams, perfumes, hair products, clothes, shoes and accessories.  By investing her Kiva loan in this season of great commercial activity, her sales have a great probability of increasing, as happens every year-end and this is what will make her Kiva loan successful.

loans.use: to buy body creams, perfume, personal hygiene products, footwear, cosmetics and feminine accessories.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: Mujer con éxitos y fracasos pero con la idea de mejorar su vida y la de su familia. Ella reside con su grupo familiar en zona con alta violencia social del país, día a día debe lidiar con ella para no verse arrastrada y afectada por ella; su familia es la razón de que ella se esmera para brindarles lo mejor. Se dedica a vender ropa desde hace un tiempo se ha hecho de personas que la buscan por su manera de atender y siempre tiene una variedad en ropa. Actualmente ella tiene el deseo de mejorar su puesto de ropa y es por eso que humildemente de acerco a INTEGRAL para solicitar un crédito y así poder comprar mas blusas, pantalones, licras, entre otros. Esta segura que con la ayuda recibida podrá brindarle un mejor futuro a sus hijos y también confía en Dios que pronto saldara la deuda adquirida. Agradece de ante mano la ayuda que recibirá, cuenta con la satisfacción de que es muy capaz de realizar todo aquello que se proponga.
texts.en:
This member has had successes and failures, but always while trying to improve her family's life. She lives with her family in a area experiencing much social violence, and she struggles every day to not be overwhelmed and affected by it. Offering her family the best is the reason she makes the effort. For some time, she has been selling clothing to people who appreciate her service and the selection she offers.

She wants to improve her clothing stall and has come to INTEGRAL to request a loan to buy blouses, pants, Lycra, and more. She is certain that with this support she will be able to offer her children a brighter future. She also believes that with God's help she will pay off the loan. She is grateful for the support she will receive and feels satisfied knowing she is capable of achieving everything she sets out to do.

loans.use: to buy blouses, pants, Lycra, and more.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is a married woman from Loon, Bohol.  She has two children ages 33 and 26.  She has been in the fish vending business for eighteen years. Her husband helps her by fishing while Juanita sells the fish. 

Aside from fish vending, Juanita has a sari-sari (variety) store business.  She plans to use the loan to buy more fish and merchandise for her sari-sari store like soap, canned goods, sugar and toiletries.  

In the future, Juanita would like to expand her business so as to have a sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: to buy more fish and merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Norberta

texts.en: Norberta is a 29-year-old married woman from Cortes, Bohol. She has no child yet. She has been in the hog raising business for four years. She has requested a loan of 9,000 to buy additional piglets, and feed (such as hog starter pellets and hog finisher). In the future, Norberta would to like to expand her business to support her family.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Eligio

texts.en:
Eligio previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and accessories and for the maintenance of his Jeepney unit. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in his family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan for him to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of his Jeepney unit and also to buy some equipment for his repair shop. Profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his family's daily needs and meet the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart. 

Eligio dreams to give his family a good future and hopes to give his children a good and quality education. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and it's where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the spare parts and maintenance of his jeepney unit.

loans.name: Nasangerel

texts.en: Mr.Nasangerel is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a Ger (felt-lined tent) in the Uvurhangai province in Mongolia. His wife, Otgontsetseg, tailors traditional Deel costumes by customers' order during winter. His two sons, Temuulen and Tuvshinbat, are 8 and 3 years old. One goes to elementary school and younger one goes to kindergarten. Mr.Nasangerel started his business in 2007 by making furniture. He has gained lot of customers' trust. His business is temporarily stopped because of a lack of working capital and raw materials. Previously, he lived in the Bulgan province and he supplied his furniture to customers in Bulgan. He used to manufacture furniture with a modern design, which is different from other furniture makers. He is a hardworking and diligent person. He needs 3,000,000 MNT to purchase raw materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to continue his temporarily stopped business

loans.name: Hasil

texts.en: Hasil is 26 years old, married and has a 2-year-old daughter. Hasil is the only breadwinner for his family. He has worked as a dentist for three years and he now needs a loan of 1000 AZN to buy necessary medicines and instruments for his profession. Hasil wants to improve his business by increasing the number of his clients so as to increase the income from his practice. He thinks that this expansion of his dental clinic will improve living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to buy necessary medicines and instruments.

loans.name: Siena

texts.en:
Siena is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling fruit and vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall.

NWTF is relisting Siena's business profile in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy repairing tools and spare parts for an auto workshop

loans.name: Bahrije

texts.en:
Bahrije is married and has four children between the ages of 1 and 6. Currently, only one child is attending school. Based on family tradition, Bahrije works as a seamstress in her own business. She is a very hardworking and ambitious woman. Her work is in much demand and seems to be required in her area, which allows her to have a higher income. 
She operates her business from home and sells locally to customers in the area. She is always busy because she has lot of orders. Her business is going very well for due to her committed effort. She has requested this loan in order to buy a sewing machine and textile materials to continue making her items. Her goal is to improve her family's living conditions and to save money towards her children’s education. 
She is very thankful for the help

loans.use: to buy sewing machine and textile materials

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: Geraldine is 40 years old, married and the mother of two children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur who earns a living by buying and selling coconut shells in the Philippines. She is requesting a loan for PHP 14000 from NWTF to buy more coconut shells to sell to her customers. Geraldine has been in this business for 15 years and her goal for the future is to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more coconut shells to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Llesh

texts.en:
Llesh is in his late 40s, is married and has three children, two of them dependents. He lives in the west district of northern Albania. In the recent years, he has been in the livestock (cows, goats and sheep) business and is happy with the progress. 
“At first it was very difficult financially because I invested in it and did not generate any quick profit; and physically because it required lots of hard labor and I suffer from a rare disease that I have been treated for in the last years. And being the only financial provider for my family was not any easier either,” Llesh explained.
Yet, thanks to his patience and hard work, Llesh has been able to establish a good clientele selling them dairy products and baby animals and generating a good income in return.
The loan he is requesting this time is to expand the goat stable and build a water well for the animals.

loans.use: to expand the goat stable and build a water well for the animals

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 31 years old and married. She has made a living through dairy farming for the past 13 years, earning a monthly income of KES 36,000.

This will be her fifth loan from KADET LTD of KES 50,000. She plans to use the entire loan to purchase another dairy cow to raise for milk production.

Her plan for the anticipated profit is to set up a bigger farm to improve the business. Her dreams and hopes for the future are to be stable and be able to sustain her family.

loans.use: to use purchase another dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes for her son's business.

loans.name: Lucilyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Lucilyn works hard to support her family.

She has a business selling used clothes in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal. Lucilyn is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase an additional bundle of used clothing to sell from her place of business.

Lucilyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 29 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional bundle of used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Victoriano

texts.en:
This is Victoriano, 43, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Gemma, a housewife and mother to their three children. Victoriano works hard to provide reliable income for their everyday expenses.

Victoriano oversees operations of a Jeepney transportation business. The business has one Jeep that carries up to sixteen passengers--most of whom come from the local community--to their destinations. He earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP from the quota the driver remits each day.

To help him continue operations of his business, Victoriano is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. He will use the loan to maintain his Jeep. He expects a boost in his income as he expands his business.  

Victoriano dreams of giving his family a good future. Every week, he faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and maintain his jeep.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pasta, oil, sodas, cheese, bread, rice, beans, and soap.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza, 26, has been married to Ngao for six years. They have two children, and Eliza and her husband are always working to give them the best.

Eliza is a native of the town of Samburu. To help her husband cover the household expenses, she started a business selling petrol.  Most of her customers are motorcycle operators.

Today Eliza is very pleased with everything she has accomplished because her business is well stocked with gallons of petrol, and she says that she has a very good customer base.

She is requesting a loan to buy more gallons of petrol to resell.

loans.use: to buy more gallons of petrol to resell.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children who all go to school. Ruth retails second hand clothes at the market, and she has been in this business for the last four years. She works six days a week. Ruth lives in her own house, and her family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.
 
Ruth has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from Kiva partner MCDT – SACCO to buy a bale of second hand clothes for sale. Her major business challenges are thieves and seasonality. Ruth's goals and aspirations are to expand her business into a big shop and, eventually, to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy a bale of used clothes for sale.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
This is William, 56, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Anabelle, a housewife and mother to their children. William works hard to provide a reliable income for their everyday expenses.

William and Anabelle operate a school supplies business adjacent to their home. There, one can buy items like pens, bond paper, and cartolina without having to go to a bookstore. William gets the supplies at wholesale prices and sells them by the piece. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, William is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. He will use the loan to purchase school supplies and expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in income as he expands his business. 

William dreams of giving his family a good life through all his hard work on his business. Every week, he faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy office and school supplies for sale.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en: Elvira is 44 years old, married and the mother of five children, four of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur who earns a living by selling vegetables in the Philippines. She has requested a loan for PHP 15,000 from NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell in her stall. Elvira has been in business for 15 years and in the future would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Chinyavu

texts.en:
Chinyavu, 42, lives with her life companion and their children in a house of her own. She sells charcoal at the market. She’s been in business for several years and has gained valuable sales experience that makes it possible for her to earn the best profits. 

Chinyavu is a humble, active woman who is dedicated to her work and who very much wants to get ahead. She’s always on the lookout for new opportunities that will make it possible for her to attain success, and she does not plan to rest until she reaches it.

In recent weeks, demand for coal has increased, and Chinyavu wants to take advantage of this to make a new investment. Thus, she is asking Yehu for a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale. She trusts this loan will help her give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Jose Rafael

texts.es: Jose, tiene 41 años de edad, casado tiene un hijo y vive en una aldea del municipio de Morazan, Yoro. José tiene aproximadamente 20 años de realizar sus propios cultivos aunque siempre se ha dedicado a la agricultura. El cultiva maíz y frijoles, pues en la zona donde vive es apta para esta producción. su mercado es local y siempre tiene clientes. Ya tuvo un préstamo anterior con ODEF y actualmente solicita el segundo ciclo y es por 7,000 Lempiras con el cual va preparar el terreno para siembra y sacar una cosecha, para eso utilizara el préstamo para comprar abonos, fertilizantes y pago de mano de obra. Para José los préstamos le han ayudado a tener capital de trabajo y evita tener deuda con los proveedores de materia prima. Su meta es ampliar la producción para darle mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
José, 41, is married and has a son.  He lives in a village in the municipality of Morazán, Yoro.  José has been working on his own crops for about 20 years although he’s always worked in agriculture.  He grows corn and beans because the zone he lives in is apt for these crops.  His market is local and he always has customers.  

He’s had a previous ODEF loan and he’s now asking for a second cycle; it’s for 7,000 Lempiras that he’ll use to prepare the soil to plant and produce a harvest.  To do so, he’ll use the loan to buy manure, fertilizer and to pay labor costs.  

For José, the loans have helped him to have working capital and avoid going into debt with his raw materials suppliers.  His goal is to expand production to provide his family with better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy manure, fertilizer and to pay labor costs.

loans.name: Ady Claribel

texts.es:
Ady, tiene 18 años, vive con su esposo y tienen una niña de dos años, ellos viven con sus suegros, ella cultiva maíz con su esposo para poder ayudar con los ingresos al hogar, tiene dos años de estar cultivando y su esposo fue quien enseñó a realizar esta labor.

Ella solicita un préstamo para comprar dos sacos de abono que son necesarios para poder aplicarlos a la milpa y que le  pueda fortalecer para que su producción sea sana, esto le facilitara el dinero para que ella realice la compra y junto con su esposo apliquen al cultivo.

Su sueño es mejorar las condiciones económicas y espera seguir trabajando con su esposo para algún día pueda construir su propia vivienda.
texts.en:
Ella solicita un préstamo para comprar dos sacos de abono que son necesarios para poder aplicarlos a la milpa y que le  pueda fortalecer para que su producción sea sana, esto le facilitara el dinero para que ella realice la compra y junto con su esposo apliquen al cultivo.

Ady is 18 and lives with her husband and they have a two year old.  They live with their in-laws, and she grows corn with her husband to help with the household income.  She has two years of experience cultivating corn, and her husband was the one who taught to perform this work.
